description.text: Printable Connect Four Game.

I searched the thingiverse for a printable Connect Four game. I found a very beautiful game here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1507 , but none that was printable.
Rules for the game here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connect_four Print one board and 42 tokens. There should be 21 tokens of two dirrenent colours. I used a raft when printing the board. The board does come out fine, but some sanding/adjustment is neccesary to clean up the tokens. At least on my printer. Created in autodesk inventor (files in zip), printed on makerbot thing-o-matic

description.text:
New revision of the plastic parts needed for a foamboard Solidoodle case cover.
The handle part is obsolete and has been replaced with the combination of the frontplate and backplate parts.
The new footplate part can be used instead of cutting notches in the bottom of the foam board. More info available at http://home.comcast.net/~tomhorsley/hardware/solidoodle/solidoodle-case2.html

For each side of the Solidoodle you need to print two of the roundclip.stl parts (which will squeeze onto the bottom left and right of the Solidoodle case opening).
The handle.stl part is obsolete, I now like the combination of the new backplate.stl and frontplate.stl parts. Cut a 15mm square hole in the top of the foamboard so the magnet will stick to the top part of the case when the backplate is inserted in the square hole. Glue the frontplate to the other side of the foamboard where the square come through so the foamboard is sandwiched between the two parts.
You can either cut notches in the bottom of the foamboard so it sits centered in the roundclip parts, or you can print 2 of the footplate.stl parts and glue them to the bottom of the foamboard to hold it centered between the clips.
For additional sealing power, stick small weatherstrip pieces to the inside of the foamboard so they seal the gaps at the edges.

This is just a frivolous imitation of a 45-RPM phonograph record, which I built to take advantage of the way my Solido SD300 builds 3D parts out of shiny PVC. But it could also work in ABS if you dip it in acetone to make it shiny! More pictures at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2012/02/classic-45-vinyl.html

Build record spiral.stl using black material, and (optionally) build label.stl in white or brightly-colored material. I posted a YouTube video that shows my model being built and how well (badly) it plays on a turntable. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WHHUFu7wgH0

comments.text: There is 3D printed record that plays on a Fisher-Price record player:
comments.author: Bluehairbob

comments.text: The Fisher-Price "record" player is actually a disc-playing music box.  The grooves contain a pattern of small posts that engage teeth that pluck the notes on a musical comb.  3D printing seems like an ideal medium to make custom music discs.
comments.author: Zomboe

comments.text: I think it would be interesting to try to print a musical comb.  I wonder how PLA and ABS would sound when plucked :).  Alternately, you could print and then tension individual strings of plastic and pluck those.
comments.author: VeryWetPaint

comments.text: These aren't really grooves because the cutter just makes a narrow 'slice' in the vinyl without actually removing any material; it's just not the v-shaped groove a phonograph needle is designed for.
comments.author: Bluehairbob

comments.text: Vinyl records are generally stamped, and the cutters make a groove with both vertical and horizontal relief (for stereo). But if you were willing to go with a victrola-style needle and horn you might get somewhere. You'd need special software (duh) possibly not even g-code-based to lay out a spiral track and impose perturbations on it. Back of the envelope says if you had a 6" diameter record moving at 45 rpm and could modulate the groove with 0.25mm resolution, you'd be able to reproduce tones as high as about 200 Hz. Cylinders might work better, but to make them work for a recording you'd need to do the outer layer as a true helix...

description.text:
This robot/armor suit action figure looks a bit like iron man or b-max (from Big Hero 6). It is nearly 20cm tall.
I really digged up the initial design. I hope you will like it remixed !

I upgraded the initial design :

  • ball joints for elbow, ankle, knee and wrist
  • added a top part for the torso aroud the neck, and making the shoulder ball joints complete (need to glue this)
  • added color inserts for the legs
  • scaled Jooxoe3i's wonderful fist and hand to fit with the new wrist ball joint

legs and hips parts are cut and have to be glued (super glue works fine). Centering pins will help positioning the parts.

Katana was cut in half. To get a full katana, katana_half + a mirrored part and then glue them together.

The figure is really poseable and can take many positions. I will probably make a pair of ninja sabers to fit with the fist.

Small tips :

  • if your ball joints are too hard to fit : use a lighter/heat gun to slightly heat up the socket part and then assemble it with the ball.
  • if your ball joints are loose : apply some epoxy on the ball or socket part with a paintbrush. Once dry assemble.
    • I can be necessary to drill slightly the hole in the hand, in order to fit the katana handle

I had a lot of fun remixing this. and then printing it !
It is really easy to print

Your turn now !

title: LG Nexus 4 Cellphone Mock-up for Cover/Case Design

description.text:
100% scale mock-up of a LG Nexus 4 phone.

Camera and speaker locations are identified via 0.1 mm deep depressions on the face and back surfaces.

Headphone plug, microphone and USB/charging port locations are deeper depressions on the perimeter.

Power and volume button locations are raised on either side.

Reverse engineered from precision 3D scan of an actual LG Nexus 4 phone.

Surface geometry and best-fit parametric data derived from captured mesh model and exported for reverse engineering.

Autodesk 123D Design used to create parametric model and export STL mesh file.

Dimensions, perimeter profile, edge radii parametric data derived from 3D scan geometry. Perimeter profile was extruded, edges filleted using best-fit parametric entities, features created and embossed or raised in the appropriate locations. Face view. Back view.

Simple Tension Tester to allow even tension measurement for belts running parallel to 2020 extrusion.

Simply Bolt the 2 arms together and place a spring between one of them and the belt clip. A rubber band around the ends of the arms should hold them secure around the extrusion.

Adjust the tension of the first belt to the desired tension and measure the spring length. This length of spring should roughly equate to similar tension on adjacent or similar routed belts.

author: jafisch248

title: Anet A8 bed level calibration test

description.text:
This is the test I came up with for my Anet A8 bed level.

It goes all around the bed 2 times and prints 2 10x10x5mm cubes in the center.

It prints 2 lines right next to each other.

If your bed level is on point, you can see a small gap between them. (picture 1)
If it's to low it presses the lines into each other. (just a bit is fine - picture 2)
If it's to high, you will see the filament not sticking to the bed.

No brim, raft, rift! No infill!

Turned out to be a pretty good testing methode.

title: Cl-260 Firmware for MKS-Gen V1.4 / V1.3 and DRV8825

description.text:
I don't recommend to use thid trlrsdr anymore as it can lead to "heating failures" with domr original PSUs and there are much more recent Marlin version, but you can use it as sample code to make your own FW
Maybe I will make a new release with the next stable or beta release Marlin

It's based on Marlin 1.1.0 RC7
Comparision to original FW: Supports much more hardware, multi-language (changeable in the configuration.h, standard is English), automatic CRC-check for SD-cards and tons of other new useful features like different ABL patterns, BLTouch, different ways of dual extrusions and much more.

Firmware is preconfigured for MKS Gen V1.4, DRV8825* and 2004 LCD** (Cl-260 standard display) but should also work with MKS Gen V1.3 as pin-layout is identical.

MKS Gen V1.4 and 5xDRV8825 can be bought cheap as SET on Aliexpress
DRV8825 drivers are more powerful, slightly quieter and slightly higher resolving than standard A4988 drivers

How to flash:
-Extract .rar file. Don't rename "Marlin"-Folder.
-Download and install Arduino IDE (V1.6...)
-(disconnect any other printers)
-Connect printer via USB to your computer, open Arduino IDE
-Select "Mega 2560" for "Board" and "Processor" in the "Tools" tab
-Select the black marked PORT in the "Tools" Tab
-Open "Marlin.ino" with Arduino-IDE inside the "Marlin" folder from the archive you extracted
-Click on "Upload"
-That's it!

WARNING:
As the seller of the Cl-260 had made some small mistakes in his building guide or made changes in his firmware over the time, you might need to change motor direction or endstop position manually on the hardware (flipping motor cables on the board or putting the enstops on the other side).
Or you can do it by software::::
After opening the Marlin.ino go into the "Configuration.h" tab
Open search function (press Ctrl+F on your keyboard)
Search a few times for "invert" and you will find all the lines necessary for invertig motor and endstop directions, the you only thing you have to do is change value from "true" to "false" or other way round for the corresponding motors/endstops and then press on "Upload" again.

*For standard A4988 and ultra smooth/quiet TMC2100 drivers you have to change one line in the configuration.h. You need to divide all the values behind "#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT" by two, as A4988 and TMC2100 can only resolve 1/16 steps, while DRV8825 can resolve 1/32 steps

**SIDENOTE: In my case the 2004 LCD display first stayed black! Cables needed to be flipped by 180° as MKS glued the jack flipped by 180° onto the board for some reason (it's not my fault/fault of the firmware, the jack is simply glued flipped onto the board). Maybe it only happened to my batch of boards but you might need to know that. To flip the cables you need to cut away the blocker on the LCD-cable-plugs with a sharp knife/scalpel first, flip them and the LCD works perfectly fine as usual

comments.text:
Original RAMPS board has good performance but breaks VERY easily
That's why I needed to buy a new board - and the next better I found is the MKS Gen V1.4
The MKS Gen is almost indestructable electrically, well made and has some more features, like one more PWM-Out which allows dual-extrusion with object cooling (RAMPs can't do object cooling when using dual extrusion), serial ports which allows to use touch-screens, a few additional pins so that you can use more precise thermocoupler instead of thermistors and many more ;)

description.text:
3D Model of OEM Lenovo T420 HDD Cover

The side furthest from the screw hole - or the side closest to the front of the laptop - has a curve. Measuring the curve is hard and so the curve will not be perfect; it will be up to you to sand it down, the same applies to any area that needs sanding.

You will need a screw to secure the cover: the one they provided me is a total of 15.13mm long with a screw shaft of 13.73mm and a 1.88mm diameter; threading is really tiny, maybe .3mm. The head is flat with a phillips driver and has a diameter of 3.62mm. Most of the threading is not used so you could easily just find a screw that is both long and thin enough to fit in the hole and I suppose just thread the new screw through the laptop's board. Without the screw, the only thing that holds the cover on is the tiny ridge on the opposite side of the screw hole and the tiny ramp on the side. I don't expect you to find the exact screw with these specifications, but I hope it helps.
Total Length: 15.13mm
Shaft Length: 13.73mm
Shaft Diameter: 1.88mm

On the interior middle section, there is a raised area that is meant to support some foam. The foam is not necessary. The screw hole does not have the "HDD" icon next to it.

This was only designed to work on Lenovo T420; the T420s is slimmer and will likely not accept this model.

"Lenovo® and ThinkPad® are trademarks of Lenovo in the United States and other countries"

I did this because this one thing cost me nearly $10, now its free

Printer:

PolyPrinter 229

Notes:

Not entirely sure what all this is. Aside from the retaining ridge, the model's thinnest points are .1mm. If this doesn't work, feel free to change the model. Would highly recommend rotating the object before slicing and sending to the 3d printer because this position is very unstable. Recommended position is the diagonal (middle) exterior.

Inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1656200 this is a generator that can be modified to fit various sizes of paint bottles, and probably also a lot of other stuff.

Update 2016-09-10:

  • Fix the grip border size (was half of intended).
  • Fix the handle hole border size (was half of intended).
  • Better generate resolution.
  • More smooth handle.

Maybe it would be nice for some to have a list of settings value to set, that fits various different lids. The default values is set to fit the sizes of the inspired tool. If you make a print that fits some other paint bottle, feel free to send a message with the config values, so that others can make it as well.

Update 2016-09-14:

  • Updated the default size to fit Tamiya Paint Mini.
  • Added test boolean to print only the grip to test size.
  • After several tests, found the ideal size for Tamiya Paint mini to be diameter=37.7

Update 2016-09-15:

  • Fixed how to set the test "boolean" so that it works with the customizer app. There is no support for booleans, so now it is a string.

I would advice people to create a test print, setting test="true"; and setting the height=2; to not wast plastic, when testing for the right grip size.

title: Nail file holder / makeup brush
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My wife likes to keep her nail files inside the medicine cabinet in our bathroom. The problem is if we lay them down they usually fall out when we open the door. We did not have a cup that fits in the space inside a medicine cabinet so I decided to print one.

I may have over did the base a bit but it does stop the cup from tipping over if you catch a nail file on it.

This nail file cup is 3 inches (75 mm) tall and about 2 1/8 inches (55 mm) wide. So I am guessing it should fit any standard medicine cabinet.

My wife also uses this to hold her makeup brushes. It is surprisingly perfect for the size. It holds a lot of brushes but is also very easy to remove them.

If you are looking for a bit larger one, check out my Unicorn version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2065359

A longer version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121914

Filament is Just PLA's turquoise:
https://www.justpla.com/turquoise-play175-1kg?search=PLAY175TRQ-1KG

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed mine with 2 walls for the top / bottom and the sides. In the inside bottom of the cup there is one small area that did not seal but I think it is because I printed mine with 2 walls.
Insert nail files and put in medicine cabinet. Enjoy your new nail file storage holder thingy.

title: Stackable vtx mount for race quadcopter

description.text:
Note that I have not yet printed one of these. Likely best printed in ABS, I would think. I only have PLA on hand. Choose your own infil percentage to get the stiffness you want. It is 2mm thick, and aimed at hosting a relatively standard race quad vtx unit, such as a 5823 or ET200 style unit. The side holes are for cable ties or other strapping solution to keep it in place, or you might also be able to put some big shrink wrap around the vtx and the board, as long as you leave the corner holes open. The notch at the top of the central open area is for the glob of solder on these vtx's that grounds the little vtx module to the rest of the circuit board. That glob often sticks up a bit, and I didn't want to stress it, so I made the notch to accommodate it. This is a standard 36x36mm board for stacking with most quad controller boards.

Let me know if it works okay... happy to make mods as needed.

BTW, the one in the photos was a laser-cut prototype... not a 3d-print. I trust that's somewhat obvious, but then I don't know what that wood filament looks like when printed. :-)

comments.text: The vtx would possibly over heat enclosed like that .
comments.author: Outbackkanga

comments.text: I wonder the same thing, but both sides are exposed to their almost full surface area.  Hopefully a good breeze will be blowing through to remove heat buildup when it's flying, at least.  If there were vertical space in your stack (unlikely, I know), I would attach a small heat sink on it to help pull the heat away.  Heck, a flat copper sheet might even be enough to help pull the heat away.  Best to remove the sticker on the metal-can part of the vtx first though.

description.text:
This is a round tray/bowl I designed to test out wood filament. It's part of ZDNet's DIY-IT Discovery Series. For more information, see the accompanying article:

http://www.zdnet.com/article/3d-printing-hands-on-working-with-wood-filament/

Also watch the video at https://youtu.be/DOSaLgZYdc0. And don't hesitate to visit http://www.zdnet.com/blog/diy-it/ and the discovery series itself at http://www.zdnet.com/article/diy-it-project-3d-printing-discovery-series/

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I used the defaults for the ColorFabb Woodfill filament

I did a ridiculous amount of sanding and attempted to finish with both lacquer and danish oil. See the video and article for details. For the record, I'm not a woodworker, so I don't really know what I'm doing. But it's a fun exploration.
There's a quick design walkthrough in the accompanying video.

This is part #120 from WLTL98761 - It may fit other models.  For that I cannot be sure.  I broke the latch on mine and required a replacement.  I didn't have a dimensional drawing of the part so I mocked on up in OpenScad and printed it.
Use original rollpin to reinstall replacement part.

author: ejchoi1

description.text:
My wife works at an elementary school running the Learning center (Library) and computer lab and this years theme is 'Learning is Our Super Power' which means the entire school decorated with Super Heroes and all things surrounding super heroes.

One of the items my wife made was a 'Kryptonite' display. We wanted to display it in a glass (plexiglass) case with steel angle iron and diamond plate. I made a base out of wood and welded the angle iron. I then designed a light fixture to light up the kryptonite from underneath using an LED Halogen replacement light.

While running my first design, we tested the light under the kryptonite and after about an hour, even though it was an led and not halogen, it was hovering at about 200 degrees Fahrenheit which was much too hot and began melting her kryptonite.

I then redesigned the light fixture to also contain two 30mm cooling fans, one pulling air and the other pushing air. My thought was to create a channel where the air would blow across the top of the light via the push/pull fans and I would enclose the top with plexiglass. I also created space in the bottom to tuck wires.

The new light fixture (the one published here) works perfectly and does not run over 80 degrees Fahrenheit.

I designed it to be mounted from under a fixture and so there are four countersunk screw holes for mounting. Also, as mentioned before, there is space under the light and under the cooling fan channels for tucking excess wiring. There is a recessed area above the light to mount a piece of plexiglass or glass.

The following are the items I used for the light:

Luxrite LR21303 7W MR16 LED Bulb, 12V, 50W Halogen Replacement:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01B1PLKYW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

LE DC 12V 2A Power Supply Adapter, AC 100-240V to DC 12V Transformer:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019Q3U72M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Mini Bi-Pin Socket up to 75 Watts Ceramic Body with Mica Covers for Light Bulbs with Base GU5.3, G4, MR11, MR16:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DQGL9T6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

30mm x 30mm x 10mm 3010S 12V 0.13A Brushless DC Cooling Fan DT:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/30mm-x-30mm-x-10mm-3010S-12V-0-13A-Brushless-DC-Cooling-Fan-DT-/262452197776?hash=item3d1b5eb990:g:xJgAAOSwNsdXRHtP

Included is the 123d Design file as well as the STL file.

description.text:
"Enemy Fish in the Water ... Release Countermeasures!"

This is recreation of a Novelty Submarine Fishing Lure I came up with about 20 years ago. This is still currently in the testing phase so I'm marking this one as "A work in progress" until I fully test it.

I've included a printed lip but I used a lip cut from a piece of .093 Plexiglass.

I used #10 Treble Hooks and #2 Split Rings on these.

Assembles just like my Crankbait Fishing Lure.


9-17-16 UPDATED - After testing the lure it was a little top heavy with the conning tower so I had to add a void to the bottom of the lure so some weight could be added to the bottom to help it float upright. (I used a trimmed down 4D 1 1/2" Finish Nail as the counter weight.) I still have to reprint it and retest it so it's still a work in progress.

If you have any questions or problems with the files or fitment of the parts just let me know and I will try to fix them.

Remember to tip your waiters designers if you like the service.... thanks for looking

This mount connects a MeFOTO SideKick360 to the end of 2020 Extrusion. Use it as a crazy strong selfie stick or with our 2020 Tripod Dovetail Plate.

The end of the 2020 extrusion needs to be tapped for a 5mm screw. Secure the SideKick to the mount and extrusion with a M5x16 screw. Then SuperGlue the plug in the large hole to keep the mount from rotating. We recommend printing with ABS and using acetone.

I was using my friend's leaf blower the other day and I was struck with how loud it was. I decided to come up with a solution. I remembered that blowtorches use the Venturi effect with gases, so I designed a Venturi tube for a leaf blower. This can be scaled in all directions to fit any leaf blower, giving you more wind per decibel that ever before!

comments.text: I always imagined it going closest to the motor, but I see no reason it couldn't go towards the tip. It probably gives a little more advantage closest to the motor however.

description.text:
Esta es una nueva versión del primero que había diseñado:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1760644

Nuevo diseño de un porta escobas ( en realidad puede portar cualquier cosa ) pero el origen de la idea fue el poder utilizarlo en un balcón como soporte para ese tipo de cosas.

Diferencias con mi primera versión:

-Ahora lo he podido exportar correctamente desde Rhinoceros y las curvas de los bordes son mas suaves.

-Le he agrandado el tamaño de las bolas para que sirvan para retener en su lugar las cosas que uno cuelga.

-Le he añadido unos ángulos para darle mayor resistencia

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
This is a new version of my previous thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1760644

New Design, Brooming Hanging ( can hold anything that you need ) but the root idea was to put in a balcony to hang this kind of things.

I hope that can be useful for you!.

Differences with my first version:

-I have exported correctly from Rhino and now the curves looks smooth.

-Added the big ball to retain the brooms or the devices.

author: chrisbradbury

title: Electronic Game Spinner Replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This was created to replace a mechanical spinner built into a board game. The spinner was hard to use and all of the game pieces moved whenever you spun it.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

15%

MPLABX PIC C Code 
#pragma config FOSC = INTOSCIO  //Internal oscillator - I/O on RA6 and RA7
#pragma config WDTE = OFF       //Watchdog timer off
#pragma config PWRTE = ON       //Power-up timer enabled
#pragma config MCLRE = OFF      //Disable master clear
#pragma config BOREN = OFF      //Disable brown-out detection
#pragma config LVP = OFF        //Disable low voltage program - free RB4
#pragma config CPD = OFF        //No EEPROM protection
#pragma config CP = OFF         //No code protection

#include <xc.h>

#define _XTAL_FREQ 4000000      //Internal oscillator frequency - Needed for __delay_xs functions

unsigned char a = 83;
unsigned char b = 179;
unsigned char c = 11;
unsigned char x = 7;

volatile unsigned char spin = 0;

void initRand(unsigned char s1, unsigned char s2, unsigned char s3){
    x++;
    a ^= s1;
    b ^= s2;
    c ^= s3;
    a = (a^c^x);
    b = (b+a);
    c = (c+(b>>1)^a);
}

unsigned char rand(void){
    x++;
    a = (a^c^x);
    b = (b+a);
    c = (c+(b>>1)^a);
    return(c);
}

void click(void){//Easiest, simplest, cheapest way to get a clicking sound that I could find
    TRISA1 = 0;
    __delay_ms(1);//Turn on piezo speaker for 1 ms
    TRISA1 = 1;
}

void led(unsigned char led){
    PORTA = 0;
    PORTB = 0;
    switch (led){
        case 0://Lets us turn off the LEDs before sleeping
            break;
        case 1:
            RB1 = 1;
            break;
        case 2:
            RB2 = 1;
            break;
        case 3:
            RB3 = 1;
            break;
        case 4:
            RB4 = 1;
            break;
        case 5:
            RB5 = 1;
            break;
        case 6:
            RB6 = 1;
            break;
        case 7:
            RB7 = 1;
            break;
        case 8:
            RA6 = 1;
            break;
        case 9:
            RA7 = 1;
            break;
        case 10:
            RA0 = 1;
            break;
    }
}

void interrupt isr(void){
    if(INTF){
        GIE = 0;
        spin = 1;//No debounce function since nothing else can happen until the spin ends anyway.
        INTF = 0;
    }
}

void main(void) {
    unsigned int i = 0;
    unsigned char curLed = 0;
    unsigned int spinDelay = 1;
    unsigned char spinValue = 0;

    CMCON = 0b00000111;//Disable comparator
    T1CON = 0b00000101;
    INTCON = 0b10010000;
    OPTION_REG = 0b11001000;
    TRISA = 0b00111110;
    TRISB = 0b00000001;
    PORTA = 0b00000000;
    PORTB = 0b00000000;

    initRand(TMR1H, TMR0, TMR1L);//Prime PRNG

    while(1){
        if(spin){

            while(spinValue > 10 || spinValue == 0){//Keep trying for a value between 1 and 10
                initRand(TMR1L, TMR0, TMR1H);
                spinValue = rand() & 0b00001111;
            }

            do{
                if(++curLed == 11)
                    curLed = 1;

                led(curLed);
                click();

                for(i = 0; i < spinDelay; i++)//Workaround. Delay maco can't be varied at runtime.
                   __delay_ms(1); 

                spinDelay += 4;//Change to vary the spin decay rate and duration

            }while(spinDelay < 100 || curLed != spinValue);

            i = 0;
            spin = 0;
            spinDelay = 1;
            spinValue = 0;
            GIE = 1;

            while(++i < 5000 && spin == 0)//Display number for 5 seconds then turn off unless the spin button is pressed again
                __delay_ms(1);
        }else{
            led(0);
            asm("sleep");
            asm("nop");
        }
    }
}

author: chrisbradbury

title: MP Mini Select Perpendicular Spool Holder

description.text:
The stock reel holder for the MPSM requires the filament to make a hard turn at the top of the printer to go into the extruder. It's also square. This causes all kinds of extra drag which nobody needs.

This is a reel adapter that attaches to the side of the MonoPrice Mini Select 3D printer where the stock reel holder goes. It holds the spool so that the filament comes over the top and straight into the extruder. It also features a ball-bearing mounted reel that can be sized to the core of the spool(s) you use, meaning that it doesn't hop and drag on the reel.

I've also included a spool that you can attach sides of whatever size you need, and use a 1" reel through its core. I use this for the $5 Filament mini-coils. Just slide them on and go.

(ISOThread.scad is adapted from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311031 by TrevM)

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Various

Notes:

There's no support needed except for the spool arms to accommodate the dovetail notch.

Print the Mini Spool with 10% infill, 1.2mm shell, support touching table for angles over 75 degrees.
Print the reels with 10% infill, 1.2mm shell, no support.
Print the bracket and the threaded rings with 100% infill, no support.
Print the arms with 20-25% infill, 0.8 shell, supports everywhere.

For every reel you print, you will need two (2) of each of the following:
22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm thick skateboard wheel bearings
M8x20 Socket Cap Screws
M8 flat washers

author: bcorbino

description.text: This is the modified Y-stage used for the MakerGear heated build platform. These files may be helpful for botters using or waiting on their HBP.

A coffee scoop/tamper made from passion flower vines.
When my scoop/tamper broke, I decided to make a new one, but do something a little more interesting than a plain handle with a bowl at one end and a disk at the other.  I like Hawaiian coffee, and have a couple other Hawaiian things around the espresso machine, so I thought I might try something tropical.  
I got some passion flower vines from the backyard and twisted them together to make a handle, and glued some of the leaves on the outside of the scoop.  I coiled some vines in a circle and pinned them to cardboard for the tamper.  Then I photographed these 3 elements and uploaded them to 123D Catch. I used macro and filled the frame as much as possible when taking the pictures, even if it meant I couldn't fit the whole object in a single frame.  I put some flour on the inside of the scoop to give it some texture.  This gave Catch a lot of detail to work with, and it did a great job. 
I scaled, edited, and mashed the parts together to make the finished scoop and ran it through cloud.netfabb.com a bunch to clean it up.

I printed this in PLA with support.  The texture was pretty rough where the support was, and I didn't have enough perimeters for the surface to be thick enough to take much sanding.  I want to try it again in ABS with a thicker shell so I can use an acetone/ABS mix for filling and smoothing. 
I've included the whole scoop, and a version split in half since my build platform wasn't big enough.

comments.text: I just wanted a regular scoop and tamper xD But this is advanced. Lol- good job though

comments.text: Very interesting idea.  It open up a lot of creative possibilities.  Photogrammetry has come a long way since you did this project.  If you did it today you could pick up the individual veins in the leaves.  Good job.

Remixed version of montereypcrepair's Ar15 Back Sight. I Remodeled the entire thing but the overall look is the same. I made it easier for 3d printing and set the file up for easy engraving (hence "Turk" in 123d file) and I use these on airsofts, not just m4s
Instructions (123d Design):
Remove "Turk" its just there as an example
Change the text or add in 2d vector (or another 3d object if you choose)
Extrude text and mirror
Place extruded text on both sides of the sight. Make sure they are overlapping!
Use the "Subtract" tool, click the sight first (as target) then click the extruded texts and press enter.
Export as 3d, STL (for 3dprinting) and to be safe check "Combine Objects"

remixed_from.author: thehans
remixed_from.title: Balloon Powered Jet Car with Sweet Rimzzz

description.text:
This is the supporting files for the Learning Blade Car Mission.

This derby car is to be used by students in the testing dependent variables while calculating the car's velocity (v+d/t). There are three independent variables that can be tested by students. See below for instruction.

Instructions

Additional Equipment needed for experiment:
4 1" Small finishing nails per car made (To attach wheels to car body)
1/4" - 3/8” Washers (for weight placement variable)
Ramp: Length should be at least 1 meter long

To set up the car use the nails as axels to attache the wheels to the Variable Car Body (see image above)

The base car is set up with 4 x 1.5” wheels, and no weights. The print files allow for students to test the how the car's velocity changes when you change one of the independent variables.

The two variables that can be changed on the Variable Car are wheel size and weight of the car.

Notes:

Depending on your printer, the Variable Car Body works best at 5-10% infill with 2 shells.

The Weight Posts should be printed at 20-30% infill with 2 shells.

title: Mad Eye Moody motorized eye patch

description.text:
This is a moving Mad Eye Moody eye patch for my mad eye costume. You can find all of the source files as well as a build log at https://cyborgworkshop.org/2016/09/07/mad-eye-moodys-magic-eye/ and a video of the eye moving here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8OwszGGdZPA and here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rj3u3MQmCE8

You don't have to motorize it, the eye will move on its own by swiveling on its access in the case. IF you do power it, a sub micro servo (specific one i used is in the build log) and a micro controller like the digispark is required.

author: CreepySandwich

print_settings.Notes:: The diameter of the tubes entering each nasal passage are very very small. You will need a very high res machine. Possibly down to 0.08mm or lower.

title: NICU Nasal CPAP cannula for babies

description.text:
This is a model for this project on Hackaday

  • https://hackaday.io/project/7295-individualised-nasal-cpap-cannula-for-preterm-kids

Babies in critical care (NICU) sometimes need nasal tubes for air etc. Nasal CPAP cannula.

But they come in only a couple of sizes for tiny babies. A baby's nasal passages are very soft and can get easily damaged and the baby uncomfortable, if the fit is not right.

This project by Ben Hartmann is to create 3D printed cannula individually fitted to a specific baby. Quickly and easily in the NICU.

This model is customisable and produces a mold which can be injected with a platinum cure silicone (baby safe) to make a cannula for a specific baby.

The 3 core measurments are the individual nare diameters (nasal openings) and the distance between them (septum distance).

These three measuremnts are the critical ones. The many other parameters are to adjust the size of the cannula and the diameter of the tubes that connect to either end.

Curvature of the entire device has not been implemenetd - more work is needed to make this better. Consider helping if you'd like (join the hackaday project).

Resolution:

0.1

Notes:

The diameter of the tubes entering each nasal passage are very very small. You will need a very high res machine. Possibly down to 0.08mm or lower.

Origin - Process

This is an OpenSCAD program which started out as just modelling the cannula shape supplied by Ben. If this could be printed directly in a flexible filament then that would be ideal. However it is difficult to print such a complex model and keep the internal area free of support structure. It could also be made in several parts and joined.

I tried this mold approach to see if a directly injectable silicone could make the end result in only two steps.

There is a problem of how much work people in a NICU can do and how automated the process can be made. Further consultation is desirable to find the best approach.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

title: SELECT MINI KNOB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like the Select Mini but it does have it's flaws. One of those flaws is the dial. It's too smooth and that makes it hard to turn. It's also located right under the bed. This means you have to be extra careful, when adjusting the dial, while the machine is printing.
I wanted a control that could be easily adjusted with one finger. I also wanted a center button. Something that was easy to locate, even when the bed was blocking my view.
I've been using this new knob for a few weeks now and I like it. I hope you do too.

comments.text: Thank you! Works (and looks) great!

Gecko Hide 1 is a hide I made for my leopard gecko.  
Gecko Hide 2 is a two part hide with a bottom for making a moist hide for shedding geckos.  
I made them in solid edge ST4 student edition. If you also have solid edge student edition, (it's free and easy to get) comment and I will also upload those files too.
These hides are somewhat large and can be scaled with no problems.

comments.text: I'm printing this now! Can't wait to see how it comes out! Thanks for the model :D
comments.author: LetsPrintIt

print_settings.Infill:: Rigid, but there is not need for a brick.

title: Stryfe - Mod Kit (Canted, 180s, Mag Release, Brass)

description.text:
This mod-kit includes all the pieces to turn your Stryfe into a competitive blaster, without breaking the bank.
Remember to slow your print for the ceiling of the motor chambers, and add some support for the protruding screw holes. Other than that, all of the parts are very straight forward to print.
The motor offset from the normal is 6.5 degrees, and they are spaced for normal flywheels.
This kit could also be used with 130s if so desired.
Have fun!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RigidBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm Vertically

Infill:

Rigid, but there is not need for a brick.
Enjoy

Mod Day

This was part of a 24 hour project to overhaul an off-the-shelf Stryfe. It worked.

comments.text: Can you flip orientation of the mag release so it resembles more of the katana mag style? The curve on it currently is a little weird.
comments.author: BigScaryBlackDude

comments.text: I no longer have a Stryfe, and so getting a reasonable placement with respect to the mag and hand would be a bit tricky. I suggest taking a crack at it yourself and posting it as a remix. If you would like the part file in something other than an STL or IPT, I might be able to help you.
comments.author: BigScaryBlackDude

comments.text: I do have a katana mag so I'll probably take it apart and model it as best as I can. Shouldn't be too hard besides getting the curve the same.
comments.author: MarkMarx1066

comments.text: So do you use this as a guide to cut the brass? Maybe so more info or pics or video showing how to install it all. Any help would be great as it looks and I know it is a great design.
comments.author: Lovinglife

comments.text: The guide can be fit over the brass, making it easier to mark and subsequently cut out the canted holes. My apologies for the lack of documentation. This was a 24hr project I did for fun. I was very pleased with the results, and if you have any specific questions, I'd be more than happy to answer them.
comments.author: Lovinglife

author: IsaakMalers

title: PL1Q Vampire, the 3d printable quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have now uploaded a new version the PL2Q Hugin
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19161 Its a 3d printable quadcopter frame that i have designed, all parts is printable. See http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DLrN-lrLtUs

I have now uploaded a new version the PL2Q Hugin
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19161 Most parts should be backwards compatible with the PL1Q with some
modifications.. if you already printed a PL1Q and want to use the
stuff like the gopro camera mount etc.. Download, Print, Build, Fly! But isn't a 3d printed arm to weak and will break in flight?
Answer here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RwZ5aTlU0iY new flight video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kSO47eAsI-E ---new 2012-02-29----- pl1q_3cmtaller_canopy.stl I have added a optional 3cm taller canopy.
Also tried reducing bridging by 50%.. ---new 2012-02-27----- pl1q_vampire_canopy2_makerbot.stl I have made a smaller canopy that should be printable on a makerbot,
i also changed the top a bit so there is no huge bridging any more.
Perhaps it is also printable upside down.. I also removed the screw
holes i think it will stick if you just push it on. If not, glue on small velcro strip on each side inside and fasten to the battery holding velcro..

description.header:
Leave a comment if you have managed printing it on a makerbot or reprap
etc..
description.text:
---older new----
I have now sliced it up to be able to print on makerbot or other
printers with smaller build area, i have not tried printing and
assembling the parts, please leave a comment if you have..
It is the files that have makerbot in their name...
Gluing would be required..and tape for the canopy..

description.header:
If someone comes up with a better idea how to make the canopy on
a makerbot that would be great!
description.text:
Presentation video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DLrN-lrLtUs I printed mine on a Ultimaker with PLA using skeinforge35. I used 100% infill on the motormounts and the arms. I used 40% on the rest. Use 100% on the landing gears if you intend to do hard landings.. Mine came out with the following weight:

total 231.6g I used a couple of drops CA (glue) to fasten the motormounts to the arms..
(not between the arms and the body, the canopy locks them in place there) It might be a good idea to print it using a different color for the front arms etc, to be able to see the orientation of it when flying. I am going to fly mine mostly fpv.. What i think is a good cheap setup for it:
(i have not tested this setup myself, its just what i would have bought
if i didn't have parts laying around) Motors: 4x A2208-17 1000KV
http://www.goodluckbuy.com/a2208-17-1000kv-outrunner-brushless-motor-for-rc-helicopter-multicopter-4-pack.html Esc: 4x TURNIGY Plush 12amp (2A BEC) BESC
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__2161__TURNIGY_Plush_12amp_2A_BEC_BESC.html Computer: MWC MultiWii Lite Lightweight Version 4-axis Flight Control Board QUADX
http://www.goodluckbuy.com/mwc-multiwii-lite-4-axis-x-mode-flight-control-board-quadx-w-ftdi-basic-breakout-.html Propellers: GAUI 330X 8" Props G-210801
http://www.gonitrohobbies.com/GAUI_330X_8_Props_G_210801_p/g-210801.htm Prop adapter: 4x 3.175mm motor shaft 5mm prop hole
http://www.valuehobby.com/3-175mm-collet-adapter-for-e300-e370-e400-e450-motors-5mm-prop-axle.html You will also need silicone wire for the motors, battery plugg, a receiver,a radio, a 3s lipo battery around 2200mAh (and a charger for it).. I am working on fpv camera mounts for it, and gopro mount.. I post it when i am finished with them.. I also have several ideas for future revisions of the quad so stay tuned, esc placement, weight reduction and so on.. :-)

comments.text: What receiver (4 channel?) and radio (transmitter) do you use? Sorry I'm new to quadcopter building and want to make sure I get the right parts :)
comments.author: approx

comments.text: My favorite radio is Turnigy 9x, and it is also very cheap just $60 from hobbyking. The nice thing with that radio is that you are able to hack it with custom firmware (if you like, not requred). It also can take plugin modules (not requried, but i like the frsky system with telemetry), i have frsky modules on mine. You can get a combopack, frsky module + one receiver for about $55.. The nice thing with that receiver is you are able to change the firmware in it so that you only need one cable between the receiver and the flight controller. (normally you need one for every channel)..

comments.text: My experience with hobbyking is that you have to put in an order even if the item is not in stock or you will never get one. Any radio with 4-chanel or more will work. If you are thinking of getting into the rc hobby, perhaps a dx6i is a good radio for you, because then you can get a lot of bind-n-fly planes and stuff that works with that radio. If you just want to fly the quad, hobbyking have a $23 radio that i think will be just fine, http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__9042__Hobby_King_2_4Ghz_6Ch_Tx_Rx_V2_Mode_2_.htmlhttp://www.hobbyking.com/hobby...

comments.text: If you printer have enough z height, it would be pretty simple to change the arms to custom length. Download the sketchup file, and open in sketchup (free) and just use the extrude tool on the top of the arm and also the same amount on the top slot of the arm.. And then export to stl, (i use this plugin http://brettbeauregard.com/blog/2011/06/sketchup-to-stl-plugin-with-no-dialogs/http://brettbeauregard.com/blo... ) I think even someone that have never used sketchup, would be able to do this in a couple of minutes after just some googling around for sketchup basics..
comments.author: mtuieee

comments.text: One other question: why a non-commercial license? This stops anyone from being able to print a set of parts and sell them to someone else that is interested in the design, but does not have a 3D printer. One of the things that has kept this hobby up for me is being able to sell random parts from time to time to buy more things for this hobby. I imagine quite a few others are doing the same.
comments.author: reprapperMC

comments.text:
It do not stop people from printing out and selling, if they have permission from the author. In the license there is a text "Waiver
Ã¢Â€Â” Any of the above conditions can be waived if you get permission from the copyright holder.". And if people with printers contact me for permission to sell i be happy to give it to them, and perhaps say please consider a donation to my paypal if you make money of my design. And if a large company
contact me and want to mass produce i will say, sure but lets make a deal. That was my thought when i choose the license i did. Hope that answered your question, and showed my point of view on it.
comments.author: reprapperMC

comments.text: Just so you are aware, the non-commercial part of the license does not do what you think. It ONLY prevents the selling/commercial display of the files. If so inclined, it can be mass produced by anyone and sold for profit.
comments.author: swepet

comments.text: Then i see no point in changing it since it would make no difference anyway. I will try to prevent people from selling it as much is i will try to prevent water from being wet. I only hope for people to contact me before they do, that's all i ask. If you don't like that thingiverse have that license as a choice then take it up with them..

comments.text: wow this is awesome! I have never seen these before. I am strongly considering building one. perhaps you could put a instructable or  tutorial together for people who know nothing about these to get started. Judging by the prices of these things in a google search this is an affordable way to get into the hobby.
comments.author: Whizbang

comments.text: I might do that when i get some more free time. It might actually be a very nice place to start with rc. You can fly in small places. With autolevel activated you do not need to keep the "balance" as you do with a normal rc heli. Parts are cheap, and the reason the motormounts looks like they do is to protect the motors incase of crashes..
comments.author: Whizbang

comments.text: I suspect you will have problems with your motors overheating based on the way you have them enclosed.  Should be interesting to see how it holds up.
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: The reason i designed the mounts that way is to save them, on my other quad i have bent the shafts in a lot of expensive motors the times the gravity won. I did some calculations, my quad consumes about 120w while in a hover, that is 30 watt per motor, if the cheap motors are 80% efficient then there is 6watt of heat generated in each motor, and i hope there is enough airflow on the top of the motors to remove that heat. But i am not sure,  for now i have just flown it in -10c.. The next quad i build might be different (and uglier), with the esc in the propwash etc
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: For the X shaped connecty bits, I've seen some people use metal arrow shafts. That may cut down on weight, but it'll definitely add strength.

comments.author: mhensen

comments.text: I printed the makerbot version of the arms today on my prusa with only 100mm Z height. They printed nice and worked great except the first pair I tried to put together ended up cracking the external part of where they fit together. I was much more careful with the second arm and with  little xacto knife and sandpaper was able to make them fit. So be forwarded!!! do not try to force them together fresh off the printer . Yo will need to sand and xacto cut in order to fit them together without breakage.

comments.text: When i started the design i thought i would use fiberglass arms, but i didn't have any. So i started experimenting with printing arms. comments.text: Love the idea but the insides would be totally impossible to clean (even with a foodsafe print from shapeways print. .. could you "thicken" or "decimate" the inside shell to make it smoother and say less complex?
comments.author: ericgus

comments.text: Gnomey mug prints just fine without support and even without smoothing the inside.  I think the slicer settings act as a low-pass filter on the really rough surface as long as the resolution is fine enough. It's a little tricky to smooth stuff out on an inside surface as I understand it.  I'll look into it though and let you know what I am able to do.  Sorry for the slow response

A mechanical endstop holder for 8mm rods. Customizable through open scad to any rod size. I created this endstop holder because the classical prusa holder was interfering with the clamps for my Z leadscrews. The holes are made for M3 screws but the scad file is provided with comments so you can adjust them to your needs. Pro:
  • smaller space used compared to classical prusa endstop holder
  • perfect balance between rigid and elastic (at least for my parts printed in PLA)
  • adjust to your needs, scad file provided
  • faster print
    • Con:
  • you have to mount the clamp to the rod before attaching the endstop.

I printed mine at 0.3mm layer height with 3 shells and 35% infill.
They work great.

I own a Plantronics 855 Bluetooth headset (http://www.plantronics.com/au/product/voyager-855) and it's one of my favourite bluetooth headsets as it's got an extendible microphone boom and it can play stereo music with AVRCP and A2DP profiles...

I also have a Plantronics Voyager Legend bluetooth and that came with a protective case, which I wish I had with the 855, because the main thing stopping me from using the 855 more often is how fragile the whole thing sits, the stereo earbud is hanging by a wire and the ear clip is easily breakable. so I took the Legend's protective case idea and designed a contoured case for my 855 too - and here it is!

This is actually version 2 - In the first version the lid clipped on very snug & tight so you couldn't get your fingers into the gap to open the lid. Also it needed a lot of attention otherwise the earbud cable is gonna get pinched by the lid. in V2 I've added a a recessed compartment to put the cable (as pictured) and deliberately raised the lip by a mm so it would create a seam between the lid and case so you can open the lid with your fingernails.

The STL file as is is designed for the 855 being used normally on the right ear. For lefties, just mirror-image the entire STL file before printing, the dimensions are symetrical.

Anyone with an 855 or looking for a good bluetooth headset, feel free to download+print this. If it's been useful to you please drop a like. Thanks! :)

A 3d printable bearing designed in FreeCad.
This was an experiment to see if it was possible to 3D print as a single object.
This bearing was my first attempt to design & print an object. The first version had 12 balls. and was a bit rough. I managed to fit 14 balls in the next design and it runs much smoother.
I first printed in ABS but found better results printing in PLA.
With ABS the balls seamed to break away and stick to the extruder during printing.
You must print with supports to hold the balls from the frame while printing.
The more attention to removing the supports from the balls will result is a smoother running bearing.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

standard

print_settings.Notes:: I use supports for the extruder motor bracket only. All the other parts can be printed without supports

description.text:
Gprint Box is an open source 3D printer that can be made in your
backyard with minimal tools and some printed hardware. With an all steel
frame this thing is a tank that can be taken into the remotest of regions.
The frame and build volume is scale able. As drawn it is 20.5 inches square and can be
collapsed into a 4 inch tall box. If you have any questions email me
[email protected] If you don't have CAD software you can use this link:

author: jonhllstrm

title: Laser cut leather watch band / strap with lining, pre-cut stitching holes and engraved groove

description.text:
This is a design for a laser cut watch band.
I used it on leather but it can be used on thick fabric too.
Using a laser cutting machine makes it easier to have nice and precise cuts on the sides, the holes, etc.

This design features pre-cut stitching holes, and engraved groove for the stich to fit in nicely, and a lining.

This helps making a nice-looking stitch and makes this project super easy : cut it, glue it, sew it in the existing holes and you're done !

You need both files for this project : one is the actual watchband and the second one is the lining.

Material :
I recommend using leather 1mm thick or less for the watch band, and very thin leather (0.2 - 0.5mm) for the lining.
You also need two needles (preferably with a round tip) and some thick thread (at least 0.5mm thick, linen or synthetic, waxed if possible).
Sew it using "saddle stich" technique (look it up, it is easy).

Instructions :
Sewing and / or glueing are required.
This thing is made of four parts, the part with the buckle (part 1) and the part with the holes for the buckle pin (part 2), the lining for part 1 (part 3) and the lining for part 2 (part 4).

Basically you fold each part over itself.
Then you add the lining, make sure to make the holes match.
Then you sew it (see photos).
I will upload a full tutorial with detailed instructions if asked.

author: Pyre

description.text: This cap is used to level the bed on the Solidoodle 2 from under the bed and without a tool. The cap fits tightly onto an M4 nut (which is 7 mm wide). No gluing is required in this design.

You will first need to purchase 6 nuts which have M4 threads. Install two nuts at the end of each bed-leveling screw on your Solidoodle. Tighten the nuts against each other. This will lock them onto the screw. Print three caps and press each onto the bottom nut of each screw. Giggity.

description.text:

I've decided to reduce the number of details to highlight those wonderful lines.
If you want to support my work, you can download the HIGH RESOLUTION STL file here :
https://cults3d.com/fr/art/mitsubishi-a6m3-zero

Working time on this model: 2 days so, don't forget to PUSH THE "LIKE" BUTTON If you like, make or download that.

I've also designed :
The Curtis P40 : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1365054
F4U Corsair : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1470382

next uploads will be :
The famous Spitfire, BF109, FW190, I16, Yak 9 or La5, P47, P51
Ask me if you search a special plane ...

------------------------------------------- en français ;-) ------------------------------------

Modélisé suivant d'anciens plans. Les dimensions extérieurs sont respectées.
Je n'ai pas modélisé tous les details pour garder uniquement de belle lignes qui rendent bien en impression 3D.

Le STL en HAUTE RESOLUTION est dispo ici : https://cults3d.com/fr/art/mitsubishi-a6m3-zero
J'ai travaillé 2 jours sur ce modèle. C'est pour ça qu'il n'est pas gratuit sur Cults mais ça m'encouragerai énormément si je pouvais gagner quelques euros pour ce travail ...

Dans tous les cas, un petit clic sur "j'aime" et/ou devenir un de mes followers ne coûte rien et motive vraiment les designers comme moi à mettre leurs modèles en ligne.

Autres avions :

A venir :
Spitfire, BF109, FW190, I16, Yak 9 or La5, P47, P51
